awd_titl_txt: Sulfur Isotopes in Subduction Systems and the Global Sulfur Cycle
awd_abstract_narration:
Sulfur is one of the most abundant elements in the Earth, is an essential ingredient for life, and plays a pivotal role in geologic and environmental processes. A large part of the global sulfur cycle involves exchange between the surface and interior of the Earth at subduction zones, where one tectonic plate sinks beneath another. As a volatile element, sulfur has the potential to be released into the Earth's mantle during the physical and chemical changes that take place during subduction. Sulfur released during subduction can be re-introduced into the atmosphere from subduction-related volcanic arcs, such as those found along the Pacific rim. While the chemistry of sulfur released at volcanic arcs has been well studied, the mechanism by which sulfur is released during subduction, and the effects of subducted sulfur on the mineralogy of the upper mantle, the volcanic arc, and arc-associated ore deposits (i.e., gold and copper), are poorly constrained. This team's work addresses this knowledge gap in the sulfur cycle by directly examining sulfur-bearing minerals in rocks from ancient subducted plates and deep arc volcanic systems, which have been brought back to the surface of the Earth via tectonic processes. 

Using a combination of field-based observations and thermodynamic modeling, one of the most important outcomes of this work will be the identification of coupled sulfide-silicate reactions that occur within subducting slabs. The oxidation state of the fluids released during these reactions has important consequences for the redox state of the upper mantle and volcanic arc system. These observations will be coupled with analyses of the sulfur isotopic signature of sulfides from exhumed high-pressure rocks and deep arc crustal cumulates, which will provide a tracer for different sources of sulfur throughout the entire subduction process. A broad range of lithologies, including meta-sediments and meta-igneous rocks, will be analyzed in order to capture the scope of subducted sulfur isotope values. In combining sulfur isotope signatures with the reactions that likely take place in a variety of subducted lithologies, the redox and isotopic composition of sulfur-related fluids that feed arc volcanic systems will be characterized in a way that has never been done before. These linkages will be tested by quantifying the sulfur isotopic signature of sulfides in deep crustal arc cumulates from the Lesser Antilles arc, which provides a novel opportunity to test how differences in subducted sediment across an arc may influence the sulfur isotopic signature in the volcanic arc. This work will provide University of Maine students with access to techniques not currently available in the State of Maine.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
In this work we combined observations of sulfur-bearing phases (sulfides) with petrographic observations (the textures of the rocks) and many geochemical tools (major elements, trace elements, and sulfur isotopes) to constrain where sulfur is hosted in subducted rocks, and how sulfur behaves when these rocks are subducted back into the mantle. Sulfur isotopes (expressed as δ34S) reveal that metamorphic rocks carry sulfur that represents the composition of the original rock deep into the mantle (down to ~80 km), and that these rocks are capable of maintaining their sulfur isotope composition at these depths. In a survey of exhumed high pressure rocks (rocks that were once subducted and have been brought back to the Earth's surface from depth) from nine difference terranes worldwide, we found that the biological sulfur signatures of seafloor rocks (for instance, that would be produced in black smoker environments) persist in these rocks even when they are metamorphosed at 2.5 GPa and 600 degrees celsius.

Combined with thermodynamic models that help us predict what happens to sulfur species in the fluids that are produced during subduction, we found that both oxidized and reduced sulfur species can be liberated from subducting slabs and rise into the arc magma system. We also found that different types of subduction zones (cold versus hot) influence what species of sulfur (oxidized or reduced) are liberated, which leads to large differences in the oxidative power of these fluids to change the redox budget of the mantle wedge. Our thermodynamic models show that there is a major redox transition that occurs during subduction when sulfides break down, and that these reactions are coincident in pressure and temperature space with major water-liberating reactions that are thought to drive the arc magma system in subduction zones. We show that sulfur can be a critical oxidizing agent for arc magmas, particularly in cold subduction zones (for instance, the Honshu subduction zone of Japan).

We also find that some trace elements (such as copper, arsenic, silver, and cadmium) are controlled by sulfides in oceanic crust, and that when these sulfides break down during progressive subduction these elements are liberated into the arc magma system. Other trace elements (nickel, zinc, gallium, and lead) are actually controlled by the silicate minerals in these rocks.

To address the magmatic arc side of the sulfur story, we analyzed sulfur isotopes in sulfides from ten islands along the Lesser Antilles arc. This dataset is the largest, most comprehensive sulfur isotope dataset from a single arc ever collected. It shows a limited range of delta values (δ34S) for nearly all of the magmatic sulfur data, which suggests that the source of magmatic sulfur along the arc is consistent. This is an interesting and kind of unexpected result given that sulfur is a volatile element. Our data suggest that the sulfur source along the Lesser Antilles is actually dominated by sulfur that is either derived from the mantle or has similar composition to the mantle.  

 


Last Modified: 11/25/2022
Modified by: Alicia M Cruz-Uribe

    Walters et al. (2020), Geochemical Perspectives Letters v13, doi: 10.7185/geochemlet.2011

    Alicia M Cruz-Uribe
    Sulfur cycling in subduction zones
